results.title: London scene
results.creator_credit: Central Office of Information and Frank Gardner
results.brief_description: A picture of life in London. Follows the course of a typical day: arrival of early-morning fruit and vegetables at Covent Garden; invasion of the City by a million workers from the suburbs; the parks of London, havens for office workers during lungh-time; diversity of shops and busy streets; the zoo; Crown Jewels in the Tower. After dark, the cry of “Time, gentlemen, please!” in the public hotels brings the day to a close.

results.title: London can take it!
results.creator_credit: GPO Film Unit, Harry Watt and Humphrey Jennings
results.brief_description: London life in the blitz is presented as ‘a series of contrasts between the ordinary and the extraordinary, the casual and the tense, beauty and destruction, stillness and action, silence and noise, light and dark’. This is surrealism based not on symbolic representation of the subconscious but on images of everyday, images transformed by exceptional circumstances of war. These images are public not private. Their power is entirely cultural and social. The commentary by American correspondent Quentin Reynolds interacts in quite a complex way with the images. Primarily intended for North American audiences, a shorter five minute adaptation called Britain Can Take It was screened very successfully in British cinemas and was something of a breakthrough for British documentary.
results.creator_credit_for_label: GPO Film Unit, Harry Watt and Humphrey Jennings

results.title: London 1942
results.creator_credit: Ken Annakin, Ralph Keene, Verity Films and Greenpark Productions
results.brief_description: A Picture of Wartime London: “A picture of London in 1942 showing a cheerful though bomb-scarred city. The streets are full of British and Allied servicemen. In the parks there are allotments; tomatoes grow on roof tops. The film shows Londoners in the Home Guard and Civil Defence. It ends with scenes of London after dark.” (Source: Films of Britain - British Council Film Department Catalogue - 1942-1943)

results.title: London's water supply
results.creator_credit: World Wide Pictures and Metropolitan Water Board
results.brief_description: Illustrates how the Board supplies some six and a half million people in and around London with water for all their needs - a daily consumption of 380 million gallons. Shows where the water sources are, water treatment, pumping, quality control and distribution, waste detection and administration.

results.title: London's country
results.creator_credit: British Transport Films, Edgar H. Anstey, Ian Ferguson, Harold Lowenstein and Syd Sharples
results.brief_description: Presents a world of wildlife and flowers and scenic beauty - where people can enjoy yachting on the Thames, or archery at Sevenoaks; riding at Knole Park, or morris-dancing at Westerham; walking over the hills near Newlands Corner, or cricket on the green at Cookham; where they can admire historic buildings - Windsor Castle, Canterbury Cathedral, Farnham Keep, the Dickens houses at Rochester, the Roman ruins at Verulamium.

results.title: London
results.creator_credit: Patrick Keiller, Keith Griffiths and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: A ‘documentary’ portrait of the capital which can variously be described as an ‘essay’ or a ‘journal’ (an interesting comparison could be made with Jarman’s ‘essay’ - The Last of England). Images of London in 1992 are accompanied by an unnamed fictional narrator, a friend and former lover of Robinson. The latter is attempting to research the city’s artistic past and support alternative paths that the city’s history might have taken. The film is made up of three ‘expeditions’ and other mini-journeys on foot. The paths taken are inspired by literary-historical concerns but contemporary political events intrude. The two reflect on how political decisions might impact upon the city’s future.

results.title: London
results.creator_credit: David McKenzie and Associated Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Travel tips”.
How do I get around in a city like London? What type of coat should I pack? What is the best time to see the Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace? Where’s an old English pub? Where should I go outside of London? These are just some of the questions travel expert Laura McKenzie answers in this fascinating tour of London. Included are day trips to Windsor Castle, Blenheim Palace, Stratford-upon-Avon, Ragley Hall and Warwick Castle.

results.brief_description: A musical tour of London showing various historical sites and icons to a selection of tunes including “Around the Marble Arch”, “Let’s all go down The Strand”, “Old father Thames”, “London Bridge is falling down” etc.

results.title: Lon Chaney: The Hunchback of Notre Dame
results.creator_credit: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
A condensed version of the classic silent film of the Victor Hugo novel which was a masterpiece of film-making. Shows details of Lon Chaney’s elaborate makeup for his role as the hunchback Quasimodo and ends with an epilogue in tribute to the remarkable star. Dubbed “The man of a thousand faces”, Chaney’s portrayal of Quasimodo is not the only outstanding feature of this production. The set which took a year to build, the enormous cast of extras and night photography adds to the epic grandeur of the film which also starred Brandon Hurst, Nigel De Brulier and Patsy Ruth Miller as Esmeralda.
